questions.text: A 56-year-old presents with fluid retention and edema. With which of the following drugs is this patient most likely being treated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Imatinib is a protein-tyrosine kinase inhibitor that inhibits the bcr-abl tyrosine kinase, which is the constitutive abnormal tyrosine kinase produced by the Philadelphia chromosome in patients with CML.
  • Imatinib is associated with the development of fluid retention, including pleural effusion, ascites, pulmonary edema, and rapid weight gain.

Imatinib:

Mechanism of Action:

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) that:

  • Inhibits the Bcr-Abl tyrosine kinase by blocking the ATP-binding site, preventing phosphorylation of downstream substrates.
  • Also inhibits other receptor tyrosine kinases, including PDGFR (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor) and c-KIT (CD117)

Indications:

  • Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML)
    • Caused by the t(9;22) Philadelphia chromosome, resulting in the Bcr-Abl fusion protein.
    • Approved for First-line therapy in chronic phase CML, Blast crisis, and Second-line therapy for CML patients progressing after IFN-α therapy
  • Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GIST): Effective when GIST expresses c-KIT tyrosine kinase

Adverse Effects:

Common side effects include:

  • Fluid retention and edema (notably periorbital edema)
  • Nausea, diarrhea
  • Muscle cramps
  • Rash
  • Hepatotoxicity (rare)

Explanation of Other Options:

Anastrozole(Option A): Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor used to treat breast cancer. It is associated with hot flashes, thromboembolism, osteoporosis, and bone fractures.

Bleomycin(Option B): Bleomycin is an intercalating agent that complexes iron-forming reactive oxygen species and induces DNA strand breaks. It is used to treat squamous cell carcinoma, both Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma, as well as testicular carcinoma. This agent is commonly associated with the development of pulmonary fibrosis.

Carmustine(Option C): Nitrosourea used for brain tumors. Toxicities cause CNS effects, pulmonary fibrosis, and myelosuppression. Edema is not typical

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with severe pain in both of her wrist joints and her fingers for the past 8 hours. She has a 3-month history of similar episodes, which are often associated with stiffness for about 90 minutes when she wakes up in the morning. Which of the following is the most appropriate acute treatment for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has classic signs of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), including morning stiffness. Her current symptoms are likely due to an acute attack of the disease.
  • Glucocorticoids like prednisolone act rapidly to reduce symptoms of severe, acute flares of rheumatoid arthritis. A short course of glucocorticoids is more effective than NSAID therapy in reducing joint tenderness and pain.

RA is a progressive autoimmune disease affecting joints and multiple systems.

Leads to reduced mobility, impaired quality of life, and shortened lifespan.

The goal of therapy is to slow or arrest disease progression using DMARDs (Disease-Modifying An tirheumatic Drugs).

Explanation of Other Options:

Indomethacin(Option A): NSAIDs such as indomethacin are a first-line treatment for mild to moderate pain relief in patients with acute flares of rheumatoid arthritis. Moreover, Steroid treatment is more effective than NSAID therapy in reducing joint tenderness and pain. NSAIDs relieve symptoms, but do not improve the prognosis.

Methotrexate(Option B): Methotrexate is the first-line DMARD for patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It is effective at preventing damage to joints. However, due to its long onset of action (weeks to months), it would not provide the fast-acting symptomatic relief this patient needs.

Vitamin D and calcium supplements(Option D): Vitamin D and calcium supplements are used to prevent osteoporosis in the course of long-term treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, but they would not help treat an acute flare.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with intermittent pain and stiffness in her hands and feet. She takes ibuprofen for the pain, which provides good relief. She had her last attack 7 days ago. An X-ray of her hands is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient presents with a history of joint pain in > 2 small and medium-sized joints. The x-ray shows joint surface destruction and narrowed joint spaces of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints. In addition, the distal interphalangeal joints are spared, which is typical for rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) and the first-line, long-term therapy for moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Early administration of DMARDs is crucial because damage to the affected joints occurs early in the course of RA. Methotrexate is highly effective, well-tolerated, and inexpensive but has a slow onset of action (> 6 weeks).

For this reason, bridging therapy with glucocorticoids or NSAIDs is normally indicated during acute attacks, but this patient's last acute attack has already ended 7 days ago, obviating the need for bridging therapy.

Methotrexate:

Mechanism of Action (MOA):

  • Inhibits AICAR transformylase, which increases extracellular AMP, which in turn converts to adenosine. Adenosine has anti-inflammatory effects
  • Inhibits thymidylate synthetase
  • Suppresses immune cells like neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes
  • Reduces polymorphonuclear chemotaxis
  • Inhibits cell proliferation, induces apoptosis
  • Minimal effect on dihydrofolate reductase at these doses (unlike in cancer therapy)

Pharmacokinetics:

  • Routes: Oral, subcutaneous, intramuscular
  • Absorption: ~70% after oral administration
  • Metabolism: Forms polyglutamated metabolites, which are retained inside cells for long periods
  • Half-life: 6-9 hours
  • Excretionis primarily through urine and up to 30% through bile
  • Interaction: Hydroxychloroquine reduces MTX clearance

Indications:

Used in many autoimmune and inflammatory diseases:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • Systemic sclerosis (skin involvement)
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA)
  • Psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis
  • Peripheral arthritis in ankylosing spondylitis (not axial disease)
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's)
  • Polymyositis
  • Giant cell arteritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Vasculitis

Dosage:

  • Start with 5 mg once weekly (oral)
  • Increase to 15-25 mg/week
  • Max effect up to 30-35 mg/week (but toxicity also increases)
  • Delays or prevents joint erosions in RA

Adverse Effects:

  • Commonly Nausea, stomatitis (mouth ulcers)
  • Due to cytotoxicity, causes Leukopenia, anemia, GI ulcers, alopecia
  • Liver toxicity: Dose-related transaminitis (elevated liver enzymes)
  • Genetic predisposition to toxicity: Mutations in CYP20A1, CYP39A1, SLC22A2, SLC7A7, ALDH2

Contraindications:

  • Pregnancy: teratogenic, must be avoided
  • Use with caution in hepatic or renal impairment

Explanation of Other Options:

Prednisolone(Option B): Prednisolone gives Temporary symptom control only, so used as bridge therapy, not long-term, not disease-modifying

Diclofenac(Option C): NSAID provides symptomatic relief only, No effect on disease progression

Adalimumab(Option D): Anti-TNF biologic, used when MTX fails or in severe RA, not first-line monotherapy

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to you because of severe progressive pain and swelling of her wrists and hands for the past 2 months. She is on methotrexate for RA, but remission could not be achieved. An X-ray of the hand is shown below. You're considering starting biologicals. What test should be done before initiating the treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has severe pain and x-ray findings of joint space narrowing, marginal erosions of cartilage and bone, suggesting severe rheumatoid arthritis (RA), for which she needs biologicals for remission.
  • All of the anti-TNF-α agents increase the risk of serious infection, reactivation of tuberculosis, and lymphoma. In an Indian setting, it's necessary to rule out latent tuberculosis before initiating the treatment.
  • If latent TB is detected, prophylactic anti-TB treatment is started before the biologic.

Indications of Anti-TNF-α agent:

Refractory therapy for chronic inflammatory systemic diseases

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Psoriasis
  • Crohn disease
  • Ulcerative colitis

Adverse effects of Anti-TNF-α agents:

  • Infections
  • Reactivation of prior infections
  • Drug-induced lupus

Explanation of Other Options:

Urine β-hCG test(Option B): Important in women of reproductive age before teratogenic drugs like methotrexate, leflunomide, etc. But not mandatory before biologics unless pregnancy is suspected.

Fundoscopy(Option C): Required before starting hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine (risk of retinal toxicity).

Serum creatinine(Option D): Important before using NSAIDs or methotrexate. Not specifically required before biologic DMARDs unless there's existing renal disease.

choices.text: To minimize adverse effects, administer folinic acid.
Pregnancy is a contraindication for the treatment.
Avoid administering NSAIDs on the same day as DMARDs.
Need yearly fundoscopy to rule out bull's eye Retinopathy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with RA comes with a 10-month history of joint pain and stiffness in her wrists and fingers. The symptoms are worse in the morning and improve with activity. She has started on first-line DMARDs. All of the following are true about treatment except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient with RA is initiated on first-line DMARDs, which would be Methotrexate

Bull's eye Retinopathy is the major side effect caused by Hydroxychloroquine, not methotrexate. So Fundoscopy is required to start and monitor Hydroxychloroquine

Methotrexate inhibits thymidylate synthetase, leading to function deficiency of folic acid, so to avoid the side effects caused by the deficiency, folinic acid should be administered 7-10 mg PO once weekly, 24-48 hours after MTX administration(Option A ruled out)

Methotrexate is contraindicated in pregnancy as it is teratogenic. If the couple plans to conceive, Sulfasalazine should be considered in patients with low disease activity.(Option B ruled out)

NSAIDs can inhibit the renal excretion of MTX, which may increase the risk of adverse effects. So NSAIDs and MTX should not be given on the same day(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with RA comes in with progressive pain. Over the next 7 weeks, prednisone is also given as a "bridging therapy" to prevent pain and inflammation while waiting for the pharmacologic benefits of methotrexate. Which of the following is a possible adverse effect of the glucocorticoid therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In rheumatoid arthritis, prednisone is sometimes used when persistent synovitis is seen in multiple joints despite a sufficient dosage of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Because it can take several weeks to months for the therapeutic effect of DMARDs to become evident, agents such as prednisone are needed as "bridge therapy" until the DMARDs become effective.
  • The major disadvantage of using glucocorticoids for an extended period is the severe side-effect profile.
  • Corticosteroids affect calcium and bone metabolism in a variety of ways.
  • For example, these drugs decrease the amount of calcium absorbed by the intestine and also increase calcium excretion through the kidneys, both of which lead to a decreased circulating ionized calcium concentration.
  • Furthermore, this process stimulates the parathyroid glands to increase the secretion of parathyroid hormone, which leads to increased bone breakdown, as the body attempts to rectify low circulating calcium levels by releasing calcium from the bones into the blood.
  • The mineralocorticoid effects of the corticosteroids can result in sodium reabsorption, potassium excretion, and fluid retention. Thus, long-term use of prednisone is associated with fluid retention (not dehydration, Option A ruled out), hypokalemia (not hyperkalemia, Option B ruled out), and hypernatremia (not hyponatremia, Option D ruled out).
  • It should also be noted that electrolyte changes also occur outside the kidney in response to corticosteroid therapy, in the gastrointestinal mucosa, salivary and sweat glands, and exocrine pancreas.
  • In the intestine, for example, glucocorticoids can increase sodium and water absorption, as well as potassium secretion.
  • Other systemic effects of high doses of glucocorticoids include adrenocortical insufficiency upon glucocorticoid removal, steroid-induced diabetes, resulting in hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, elevated glucagon, and hypocalcemia

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of severe recalcitrant plaque psoriasis comes to the physician because of a recurrence of erythematous plaques despite current treatment measures. Treatment is begun with a calcineurin inhibitor that binds cyclophilin and blocks T cell activation by preventing IL-2 transcription. This patient is at greatest risk of experiencing which of the following adverse effects as a result of this drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor that induces immunosuppression by binding cyclophilin and inhibiting interleukin (IL)-1 and IL-2 receptor production, and inhibits macrophage/T-cell interaction and T-cell responsiveness through the regulation of gene transcription.
  • Cyclosporine is used in the treatment of transplant rejection prophylaxis, severe psoriasis, and rheumatoid arthritis
  • Nephrotoxicity, characterized by an elevated BUN (>35-45 mg/dL) and creatinine (>2.0-2.5 mg/dL), is the most common adverse effect of systemic cyclosporine therapy and has been documented in all types of patients who are receiving cyclosporine.
  • Factors that increase the risk of nephrotoxicity with cyclosporine include age older than 50 years, concomitant nephrotoxic medications, and the period 6 to 8 weeks posttransplant (if used in transplant rejection prophylaxis).
  • Cyclosporine-induced nephrotoxicity is most likely due to intense renal vasoconstriction, which leads to increases in serum creatinine, arterial blood pressure, and serum potassium. Cyclosporin causes nephrotoxicity, severe hypertension, gingival hyperplasia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperglycemia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Corneal deposits(Option A): Corneal deposits are not a side effect of cyclosporine; however, it is commonly seen with hydroxychloroquine usage.

Hypotension(Option B): Cyclosporine typically causes hypertension, not hypotension.

Seizures(Option D): Possible with cyclosporine-induced neurotoxicity, but less common than nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought in with a fever of 101 F, rash, and urticaria. His mother states that he has been complaining about pain in his hands, wrists, and knees. He has a recent history of an upper respiratory tract infection, for which he completed a 5-day course of Cefexime. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Serum sickness is a type Ill hypersensitivity reaction that is commonly caused by a reaction to certain Key features of serum sickness are rash, fever, and polyarthralgias or polyarthritis, which begin one to two weeks after exposure to the responsible agent. Patients are often extremely ill during the febrile stage, but serum sickness is self-limited, and once the responsible drug is discontinued, the prognosis is excellent.
  • Due to the severity of the signs and symptoms in this patient, oral prednisone and diphenhydramine should be administered. The glucocorticoid prednisone will treat the arthralgias and the skin rash, and the diphenhydramine will alleviate the urticaria.
  • In serum sickness, it is suggested that the drug acts as a hapten, which binds to serum or cell-bound proteins. This drug-protein complex is recognized as being foreign to the body and induces serum sickness.
  • Medications commonly associated with the development of this condition include cephalosporins (especially cefaclor), penicillins, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, vaccines, antitoxins, hormones from other species, tetracyclines, captopril, and ciprofloxacin.
  • Common signs and symptoms of serum sickness include fever, cutaneous eruptions, lymphadenopathy, and arthralgias. The reaction is generally delayed for 5 to 10 days after initial exposure, because it takes that long for the generation of specific IgG antibodies.
  • Treatment measures include withdrawal of the causative agent, symptomatic treatment (antihistamines for urticaria), and glucocorticoids.
  • Due to the severity of the signs and symptoms in this patient, oral prednisone and diphenhydramine should be administered. The glucocorticoid prednisone will treat the arthralgias and the skin rash, and the diphenhydramine will alleviate the urticaria.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aspirin and diphenhydramine(Option B): Aspirin is not indicated and may increase the risk of Reye's syndrome in children

Azithromycin and diphenhydramine(Option C): No indication for antibiotics (no ongoing infection)

Betamethasone and erythromycin(Option D): Again, unnecessary antibiotic; betamethasone could help, but oral prednisone is preferred in systemic cases

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a renal allograft is currently taking an immunosuppressive drug. Laboratory examination shows a uric acid level of 10.5 mg/dL. Treatment with allopurinol is begun, necessitating a reduction in the dose of the immunosuppressive drug. Which of the following immunosuppressive drugs is this patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this question, you must identify the immunosuppressive drug that interacts with allopurinol, subsequently requiring a dose reduction of the immunosuppressant agent.
  • Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that ultimately inhibits T-lymphocyte proliferation. This agent is converted to 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits DNA purine synthesis and subsequent T-cell proliferation.
  • Xanthine oxidase is instrumental in the metabolism of azathioprine metabolites, and coadministration with allopurinol (an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase) can result in azathioprine toxicity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Abatacept(Option A): A T-cell co-stimulation blocker (inhibits CD80/86 interaction with CD28). Used mainly for rheumatoid arthritis, not transplant rejection. No known interaction with allopurinol.

Cyclosporine(Option C): A calcineurin inhibitor that suppresses IL-2 transcription to prevent T-cell activation. Its side effects include nephrotoxicity, hypertension, and neurotoxicity, but it does not interact with allopurinol.

Mycophenolate mofetil(Option D): Inhibits inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase, blocking guanine nucleotide synthesis. Selectively affects lymphocytes (T and B cells). No xanthine oxidase metabolism, hence no interaction with allopurinol.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a recent liver transplant is on a drug that reduces the activation of cytotoxic T lymphocytes by inhibiting IL-2 transcription to prevent transplant rejection. This additional drug is most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tacrolimus inhibits calcineurin-mediated transcription of IL-2. Tacrolimus binds to an immunophilin called FK binding protein 12 (FKBP12), and produces immunosuppression by a mechanism that involves inhibition of the first phase of T-cell activation.
  • It is indicated for heart, liver, and kidney transplant prophylaxis. It has also been used in the treatment of severe cases of ulcerative colitis and eczema. This drug is associated with the development of thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, nephrotoxicity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, tremor, and CNS toxicity.

Explanation of Other Options:

Azathioprine(Option A): Azathioprine is converted to 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits DNA synthesis and subsequent cell proliferation. It is indicated for kidney transplant rejection and severe rheumatoid arthritis. It has also been used in the treatment of Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. This drug is associated with the development of leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.

Cyclophosphamide(Option B): Cyclophosphamide inhibits cell proliferation by alkylating DNA. This agent has been used in the treatment of a variety of cancers, such as leukemia, lymphoma, multiple myeloma, breast cancer, and ovarian cancer, as well as mycosis fungoides. This drug has also been used in the treatment of severe rheumatoid arthritis unresponsive to other disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARD) therapies. Cyclophosphamide causes hemorrhagic cystitis, urinary bladder fibrosis, heart failure, immunosuppression, and anemia.

Sirolimus(Option C): Like tacrolimus, sirolimus binds FKBP12, but sirolimus does not inhibit calcineurin or block cytokine gene transcription in T cells; rather, sirolimus inhibits the mammalian targets of rapamycin (mTOR), leading to the blockage of IL-2 cytokine signaling. By blocking mTOR, sirolimus inhibits the cellular response to IL-2 and inhibits the progression of the cell cycle, thereby prohibiting T cell proliferation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with hepatitis B virus develops fulminant hepatitis. A liver transplant is successfully performed, and treatment is begun with an immunosuppressant. You recommend avoiding the consumption of grapefruit and grapefruit juice when taking this drug. Which of the following is the most likely immunosuppressant administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cyclosporine is indicated for the prevention of renal, cardiac, and liver transplant rejection, as well as the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be effective in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's).
  • Calcineurin normally stimulates transcription factors that lead to increased production of interleukin 2 and related cytokines. Thus, cyclosporine decreases the production of IL-2.
  • Cyclosporine has many drug interactions because the CYP3A enzyme system largely metabolizes it; compounds that alter the activity of this enzyme also affect cyclosporine levels. Grapefruit juice inhibits CYP3A, resulting in increased blood concentrations of cyclosporine.
  • Common adverse effects seen with cyclosporine include elevated BUN, hypertension, tremor, infection, and renal impairment. Serious reactions include severe hypertension, severe hyperkalemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, neutropenia, immunosuppression, nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, seizures, and opportunistic infections.

Explanation of Other Options:

Azathioprine(Option A): It's a prodrug that converts to 6-mercaptopurine. Inhibits purine synthesis, suppressing both B and T lymphocyte proliferation. Mainly via xanthine oxidase and thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT). Not metabolized by CYP3A4.

Muromonab-CD3(Options C): A monoclonal antibody against the CD3 receptor on T-cells. As a monoclonal antibody, it's degraded by proteolysis, not via liver enzymes like CYP450.

Mycophenolate mofetil(Option D): Prodrug of mycophenolic acid. Undergoes glucuronidation, not CYP450-mediated.
